answers.answer: Hi there and welcome.  Well, congratulations on your pregnancy and you are almost finished with it!!  Trust me, your little one will be here before you know it as time flies by so hang in there!!I had pregnancy hypertension.  This can lead to preeclampsia.  I didn't develop it.  It is my understanding that hypertension during pregnancy is a bit different than regular hypertension.  While I have greater odds of eventually developing hypertension later in life, my blood pressure went back to normal upon giving birth.  So, I tell you this because if you were to develoop preeclampsia, it would not be due to anxiety.  Sure, stress is a factor in blood pressure----  but again, pregnacy hypertension is different.  So, try not to worry about that.I would picture and visualize that a lot of what you are feeling is due strictly to the additional hormones floating around in you.  They are responsible for growing your beautiful baby but do tend to make us more vulnerable to difficult and uncomfortable emotions.  So, put the hormones in their place.  They are just a temporary inconvenience!!  They do not own you but just have to be dealt with during pregnancy.  It really helps me to visualize things like that to help me feel in control of what is going on in my body.  YOU are the boss of the hormones and you tell them to quiet down.Really important to do all the 'other' things right now if you are not taking medication as you usually do.  This includes speaking with a therapist.  This would be so important now as a source to vent your fears and put them in perspective!  I'd also make sure you exercise in moderation each and every day as this helps regulate mood and relieve stress (not to mention---  good for your heart.)  Not sure what your exercise level was before pregnancy but certainly a brisk walk daily would be great.  They have yoga programs for pregnant women.  Eat well.  Medication is calming.  Use some deep breathing techniques (square breathing is one, breath in for 4, hold 4, breath out for 4, hold 4, repeat).  Spend time with friends/family, stay active.  Play music you love around the house, garden, whatever gives you calming pleasure.And if it intensifies, do talk to your doctor again.Don't worry about preeclampsia.  You say that your blood pressure has been good during the pregnancy so this should not be something you fear.  good luck
